comment_text.mn114:1.1: The Buddha begins by speaking of what should and should not be cultivated. Then he goes on to offer three distinct analyses of this, each laid out in a series of dichotomies. After each one, Sāriputta offers a lengthy elaboration, which the Buddha then approves and recapitulates.
comment_text.mn114:2.1: To “cultivate” is to foster or nurture through repeated association or practice.
comment_text.mn114:3.1: The first analysis consists of seven items: bodily, verbal, and mental conduct; arising of thought; and acquisition of perception, views, and reincarnation.
comment_text.mn114:3.19: “Life-form” is attabhāva, literally the “state of the self”, where the “self” comes close in meaning to “body”—whether material or immaterial—which is a secondary sense of ātman in the Upaniṣads. Accordingly, the commentary to AN 5.100 glosses as sarīrapaṭilābha. | “Reincarnation” is paṭilābha. In the 20th century, Buddhist writers shied away from using “reincarnation”, which they associated with the Hindu idea of a transmigrating soul. But there is nothing in the word “reincarnation” that implies a soul. Rather, it simply refers to going into another body, which is precisely what is meant by attabhāva. It is unwise to hang a heavy philosophical cloak upon the feeble hook of a single word.
comment_text.mn114:4.1: Sāriputta proceeds to elaborate each of the seven items in turn.
comment_text.mn114:5.8: This includes the first three precepts, or else the first three of the ten ways of skillful deeds.
comment_text.mn114:6.8: This is the four verbal ways of skillful deeds.
comment_text.mn114:7.8: This is the final three ways of skillful deeds.
comment_text.mn114:8.8: The discussions at MN 8:13.1 and AN 7.53 show that this refers to the initial thought that precedes action.
comment_text.mn114:10.8: A view is a perception solidified into a persistent pattern of thought, which becomes a way of seeing the world. View offer explanatory power, provide us with a convenient template for understanding, and often dismissing, what we encounter. Once a view has set in, it tends to reinforce itself, and hence is very slow to change.
comment_text.mn114:11.10: As the examples will show, this refers to a kind of rebirth that is not conducive to developing wholesome qualities.
comment_text.mn114:11.11: Apariniṭṭhitabhāvāya (“not for the sake of the state of perfection”) is found only here. The commentary explains it in terms of individuals who are reborn in a painful state where they are unable to realize the accomplishment of liberation.
comment_text.mn114:11.12: The question is absent in the Mahāsaṅgīti edition, but present in the PTS and BJT editions.
comment_text.mn114:12.1: This completes the elaboration of the seven items.
comment_text.mn114:22.1: Now the Buddha introduces the second analysis, in terms of the six senses.
comment_text.mn114:23.2: Sāriputta proceeds to elaborate these six items in terms of what gives rise to the skillful and unskillful.
comment_text.mn114:39.1: The Buddha introduces the third and final analysis, which shifts to the requisites and residence of a monastic.

root_text.mn114:16.3: adinnādānaṁ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, yaṁ taṁ parassa paravittūpakaraṇaṁ gāmagataṁ vā araññagataṁ vā taṁ nādinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādātā hoti;
root_text.mn114:16.4: kāmesumicchācāraṁ pahāya kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, yā tā māturakkhitā piturakkhitā mātāpiturakkhitā bhāturakkhitā bhaginirakkhitā ñātirakkhitā gottarakkhitā dhammarakkhitā sassāmikā saparidaṇḍā antamaso mālāguḷaparikkhittāpi tathārūpāsu na cārittaṁ āpajjitā hoti—
root_text.mn114:16.5: evarūpaṁ, sāriputta, kāyasamācāraṁ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
root_text.mn114:16.9: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ mayā idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
root_text.mn114:20.6: Yathārūpaṁ, sāriputta, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṁ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti evarūpo attabhāvapaṭilābho na sevitabbo;
root_text.mn114:20.7: yathārūpañca kho, sāriputta, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṁ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti—
root_text.mn114:21.1: Kathaṁrūpaṁ, sāriputta, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṁ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti?
root_text.mn114:21.2: Sabyābajjhaṁ, sāriputta, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṁ abhinibbattayato apariniṭṭhitabhāvāya akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
root_text.mn114:21.3: abyābajjhaṁ, sāriputta, attabhāvapaṭilābhaṁ abhinibbattayato pariniṭṭhitabhāvāya akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
root_text.mn114:21.7: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ mayā idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.

translation_text.mn114:0.2: What Should and Should Not Be Cultivated
translation_text.mn114:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn114:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn114:2.1: “Mendicants, I will teach you an exposition of the teaching on what should and should not be cultivated.
translation_text.mn114:2.2: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn114:3.1: “I say that there are two kinds of bodily behavior:
translation_text.mn114:3.2: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:3.3: And each of these is a kind of bodily behavior.
translation_text.mn114:3.4: I say that there are two kinds of verbal behavior:
translation_text.mn114:3.5: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:3.6: And each of these is a kind of verbal behavior.
translation_text.mn114:3.7: I say that there are two kinds of mental behavior:
translation_text.mn114:3.8: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:3.9: And each of these is a kind of mental behavior.
translation_text.mn114:3.10: I say that there are two arisings of thought:
translation_text.mn114:3.11: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:3.12: And each of these is an arising of thought.
translation_text.mn114:3.13: I say that there are two acquisitions of perception:
translation_text.mn114:3.14: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:3.15: And each of these is an acquisition of perception.
translation_text.mn114:3.16: I say that there are two acquisitions of views:
translation_text.mn114:3.17: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:3.18: And each of these is an acquisition of views.
translation_text.mn114:3.19: I say that there are two kinds of incarnation:
translation_text.mn114:3.20: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:4.1: When he said this, Venerable Sāriputta said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn114:4.2: “Sir, this is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.
translation_text.mn114:5.1: ‘I say that there are two kinds of bodily behavior:
translation_text.mn114:5.2: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:5.3: And each of these is a kind of bodily behavior.’
translation_text.mn114:5.5: but why did he say it?
translation_text.mn114:5.6: You should not cultivate the kind of bodily behavior which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn114:5.7: And you should cultivate the kind of bodily behavior which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn114:5.8: And what kind of bodily behavior causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline?
translation_text.mn114:5.9: It’s when someone kills living creatures. They’re violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings.
translation_text.mn114:5.10: They steal. With the intention to commit theft, they take the wealth or belongings of others from village or wilderness.
translation_text.mn114:5.11: They commit sexual misconduct. They have sexual relations with women who have their mother, father, both mother and father, brother, sister, relatives, or clan as guardian. They have sexual relations with a woman who is protected on principle, or who has a husband, or whose violation is punishable by law, or even one who has been garlanded as a token of betrothal.
translation_text.mn114:5.12: That kind of bodily behavior causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn114:5.13: And what kind of bodily behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow?
translation_text.mn114:5.14: It’s when someone gives up killing living creatures. They renounce the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
translation_text.mn114:5.15: They give up stealing. They don’t, with the intention to commit theft, take the wealth or belongings of others from village or wilderness.
translation_text.mn114:5.16: They give up sexual misconduct. They don’t have sexual relations with women who have their mother, father, both mother and father, brother, sister, relatives, or clan as guardian. They don’t have sexual relations with a woman who is protected on principle, or who has a husband, or whose violation is punishable by law, or even one who has been garlanded as a token of betrothal.
translation_text.mn114:5.17: That kind of bodily behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn114:5.18: ‘I say that there are two kinds of bodily behavior:
translation_text.mn114:5.19: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:5.20: And each of these is a kind of bodily behavior.’
translation_text.mn114:5.21: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.
translation_text.mn114:6.1: ‘I say that there are two kinds of verbal behavior:
translation_text.mn114:6.2: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:6.3: And each of these is a kind of verbal behavior.’
translation_text.mn114:6.5: but why did he say it?
translation_text.mn114:6.6: You should not cultivate the kind of verbal behavior which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn114:6.7: And you should cultivate the kind of verbal behavior which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn114:6.8: And what kind of verbal behavior causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline?
translation_text.mn114:6.9: It’s when someone lies. They’re summoned to a council, an assembly, a family meeting, a guild, or to the royal court, and asked to bear witness: ‘Please, worthy man, say what you know.’ Not knowing, they say ‘I know.’ Knowing, they say ‘I don’t know.’ Not seeing, they say ‘I see.’ And seeing, they say ‘I don’t see.’ So they deliberately lie for the sake of themselves or another, or for some trivial worldly reason.
translation_text.mn114:6.10: They speak divisively. They repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. And so they divide those who are harmonious, supporting division, delighting in division, loving division, speaking words that promote division.
translation_text.mn114:6.11: They speak harshly. They use the kinds of words that are cruel, nasty, hurtful, offensive, bordering on anger, not leading to immersion.
translation_text.mn114:6.12: They talk nonsense. Their speech is untimely, and is neither factual nor beneficial. It has nothing to do with the teaching or the training. Their words have no value, and are untimely, unreasonable, rambling, and pointless.
translation_text.mn114:6.13: That kind of verbal behavior causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn114:6.14: And what kind of verbal behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow?
translation_text.mn114:6.15: It’s when a certain person gives up lying. They’re summoned to a council, an assembly, a family meeting, a guild, or to the royal court, and asked to bear witness: ‘Please, worthy man, say what you know.’ Not knowing, they say ‘I don’t know.’ Knowing, they say ‘I know.’ Not seeing, they say ‘I don’t see.’ And seeing, they say ‘I see.’ So they don’t deliberately lie for the sake of themselves or another, or for some trivial worldly reason.
translation_text.mn114:6.16: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
translation_text.mn114:6.17: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
translation_text.mn114:6.18: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
translation_text.mn114:6.19: That kind of verbal behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn114:6.20: ‘I say that there are two kinds of verbal behavior:
translation_text.mn114:6.21: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:6.22: And each of these is a kind of verbal behavior.’
translation_text.mn114:6.23: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.
translation_text.mn114:7.1: ‘I say that there are two kinds of mental behavior:
translation_text.mn114:7.2: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:7.3: And each of these is a kind of mental behavior.’
translation_text.mn114:7.5: but why did he say it?
translation_text.mn114:7.6: You should not cultivate the kind of mental behavior which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn114:7.7: And you should cultivate the kind of mental behavior which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn114:7.8: And what kind of mental behavior causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline?
translation_text.mn114:7.9: It’s when someone is covetous. They covet the wealth and belongings of others: ‘Oh, if only their belongings were mine!’
translation_text.mn114:7.10: They have ill will and malicious intentions: ‘May these sentient beings be killed, slaughtered, slain, destroyed, or annihilated!’
translation_text.mn114:7.11: That kind of mental behavior causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn114:7.12: And what kind of mental behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow?
translation_text.mn114:7.13: It’s when someone is content. They don’t covet the wealth and belongings of others: ‘Oh, if only their belongings were mine!’
translation_text.mn114:7.14: They have a kind heart and loving intentions: ‘May these sentient beings live free of enmity and ill will, untroubled and happy!’
translation_text.mn114:7.15: That kind of mental behavior causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn114:7.16: ‘I say that there are two kinds of mental behavior:
translation_text.mn114:7.17: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:7.18: And each of these is a kind of mental behavior.’
translation_text.mn114:7.19: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.
translation_text.mn114:8.1: ‘I say that there are two arisings of thought:
translation_text.mn114:8.2: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:8.3: And each of these is an arising of thought.’
translation_text.mn114:8.5: but why did he say it?
translation_text.mn114:8.6: You should not cultivate the arising of thought which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn114:8.7: And you should cultivate the arising of thought which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn114:8.8: And what arising of thought causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline?
translation_text.mn114:8.9: It’s when someone is covetous, and lives with their heart full of covetousness.
translation_text.mn114:8.10: They are malicious, and live with their heart full of ill will.
translation_text.mn114:8.11: They’re hurtful, and live with their heart intent on harm.
translation_text.mn114:8.12: That arising of thought causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn114:8.13: And what arising of thought causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow?
translation_text.mn114:8.14: It’s when someone is content, and lives with their heart full of contentment.
translation_text.mn114:8.15: They have good will, and live with their heart full of good will.
translation_text.mn114:8.16: They’re kind, and live with their heart full of kindness.
translation_text.mn114:8.17: That arising of thought causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn114:8.18: ‘I say that there are two arisings of thought:
translation_text.mn114:8.19: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:8.20: And each of these is an arising of thought.’
translation_text.mn114:8.21: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.
translation_text.mn114:9.1: ‘I say that there are two acquisitions of perception:
translation_text.mn114:9.2: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:9.3: And each of these is an acquisition of perception.’
translation_text.mn114:9.5: but why did he say it?
translation_text.mn114:9.6: You should not cultivate the acquisition of perception which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn114:9.7: And you should cultivate the acquisition of perception which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn114:9.8: And what acquisition of perception causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline?
translation_text.mn114:9.9: It’s when someone is covetous, and lives with their perception full of covetousness.
translation_text.mn114:9.10: They are malicious, and live with their perception full of ill will.
translation_text.mn114:9.11: They’re hurtful, and live with their perception intent on harm.
translation_text.mn114:9.12: That acquisition of perception causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn114:9.13: And what acquisition of perception causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow?
translation_text.mn114:9.14: It’s when someone is content, and lives with their perception full of contentment.
translation_text.mn114:9.15: They have good will, and live with their perception full of good will.
translation_text.mn114:9.16: They’re kind, and live with their perception full of kindness.
translation_text.mn114:9.17: That acquisition of perception causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn114:9.18: ‘I say that there are two acquisitions of perception:
translation_text.mn114:9.19: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:9.20: And each of these is an acquisition of perception.’
translation_text.mn114:9.21: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.
translation_text.mn114:10.1: ‘I say that there are two acquisitions of views:
translation_text.mn114:10.2: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:10.3: And each of these is an acquisition of views.’
translation_text.mn114:10.5: but why did he say it?
translation_text.mn114:10.6: You should not cultivate the acquisition of views which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn114:10.7: And you should cultivate the acquisition of views which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn114:10.8: And what acquisition of views causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline?
translation_text.mn114:10.9: It’s when someone has such a view:
translation_text.mn114:10.10: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
translation_text.mn114:10.11: That acquisition of views causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn114:10.12: And what acquisition of views causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow?
translation_text.mn114:10.13: It’s when someone has such a view:
translation_text.mn114:10.14: ‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are such things as mother and father, and beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
translation_text.mn114:10.15: That acquisition of views causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn114:10.16: ‘I say that there are two acquisitions of views:
translation_text.mn114:10.17: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.
translation_text.mn114:10.18: And each of these is an acquisition of views.’
translation_text.mn114:10.19: That’s what the Buddha said, and this is why he said it.
